Posts.Content: Hello Jenny, I had a similar problem and eventually discovered the Genie bras which are made of a soft but very supportive material and there are no hooks to do up! You can slip them over your head or if you have restricted arm movement you can pull them up. They also have "pockets" to place a supportive cup in or your prosthesis if you have one. I had an immediate reconstruction done after my mx but struggled with normal bras but found the genie bras really comfortable and although I am back in normal bras now after nearly eighteen months I still wear the genie bras at night. You can buy them from High street TV (online shopping) or some of the stores like BHS, Boots and Asda stock them. I hope this helps and wish you well with your recovery. Xx
Posts.Title: comfy bra

Posts.Content: Hi Alaval 100, just noticed from your post that you had an LD reconstruction and were going to have radiotherapy. Have you had the treatment yet? If so, has it affected your reconstruction in any way? Mine is a long story, I also had an LD done two years ago but due to a returning tumour have recently had a WLE and will be having radiotherapy too. Xx
Posts.Title: Round block mammoplasty

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say a big thank you to all of you who replied to my post. I went to the hospital yesterday for fourth FEC, had a heated wheat bag on my hand and arm on the way there to keep veins warm! The nurse managed to find a reasonable vein and applied some anaesthetic to it first and thankfully it worked...needle went in no problem and treatment went ahead! I was so relieved because I think if it hadn't worked this time I would have just given up....still two more to go! Xx
Posts.Title: FEC - unco-operative veins!!!....and advice on PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi, I too have suffered from a very dry mouth while having FEC (4 out of 6 done), my oncologist was no help with this but then I came across a Macmillan trained pharmacist at my local Boots store and she suggested a spray called Glandusan. It comes in two flavours and you just spray it into your mouth when it is dry and it really helps to put the moisture back into your mouth, I think you can get it on prescription but I just bought it because I felt quite desperate, used to wake up gagging at night! You can also get some pastilles to suck which are supposed to do a similar thing but I cannot remember what these were called. It is a good idea to see if there is a Macmillan trained pharmacist at a Boots store somewhere near you because they seem to be very knowledgeable and helpful in cancer related matters....found mine more useful than the chemo nurse! She was also able to suggest things for my dry eyes, my nose ( a little coating of vaseline just inside your nostrils helps with the dryness and acts as a barrier in place of the nose hairs that have gone!) and stuff to help with my bowel problems! Hope this is of some help to you. All the best xx
Posts.Title: Dry mouth after AC chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi All, on Tuesday I went to have my 4th FEC treatment but unfortuantely my veins were not having any if it! The chemo nurse tried seven different veins but each time she put the needle in, the vein just seemed to shrink and she wasn't getting any "flashback" as she put it. I finally had enough and asked her to stop trying....came home feeling very upset with a very painful arm covered in bruises! I am supposed to go again tomorrow to try again but am so worried....arm doesn't seem to have recovered yet....what if she can't get the needle in again?! Has anyone else experienced this? She did mention Picc line but said it was probably late to do this? Has anyone had this and how did you manage with it? Also said she had once put the treatment into a patients foot! I get lymphoeadma in the other other arm so don't want that to be touched! Any thoughts or advice greatly appreciated. Xx
Posts.Title: FEC - unco-operative veins!!!....and advice on PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi Louise, just wanted to let you know that I am thinking of you and hope everything goes well tomorrow at the Royal Marsden. So glad that your CT scan was clear. I am recovering ok after surgery, results not as good as expected and will be seeing oncologist some time this week for treatment plan. I have replied to your pm but don't know if it has got through so thought i would try this way. All the best xx
Posts.Title: Message for Aroma mum

Posts.Content: Hi, thanks for the reply. My BC is ER+ too, I was diagnosed with diabetes only a few months before being diagnosed with the cancer! I haven't had many problems with the Metformin, it did upet my stomach for a few weeks at first and I also had a metallic taste in my mouth but nothing too worrying. I was put on tamoxifen for five years but found the side effects of that quite unbearable and decided to stop taking it after discussing with my surgeon....the benefits of it were not enough to make a big difference in my case. Also the long term effects of being a diabetic combined with the side effects of the tamoxifen were not worth taking a risk in my case....So maybe the Metformin may help me instead! Good luck with the trial and all the best for the New Year x
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Hi, just curious to know what this trial is? I am a diabetic and am taking metformin anyway to control this, how does it help with the breast cancer? Thanks
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I have not been on the site for a while but still regularly look at the discussions and I am hoping someone might be able to help me with a query. I am turning 50 at the end of September, my hubby and daughters feel that a we should celebrate by going on an adventurous Â exotic holiday! However, I had FEC chemotherapy treatment last year and am not sure what this has done to any previous vaccinations/immunisations I had. Would they have been wiped out by the chemo? Would I have to have them done again and how do I find out if this is necessary? Any advice would be greatly appreciated! Thanks
Posts.Title: Life after chemo - immunisations/vaccinations

Posts.Content: Hi All, just wanted to say a big thank you to everyone who replied to my post....you are all so wonderful and the advice was all helpful. I did speak to my chemo nurse yesterday who advised me to go to the GP, managed to see a doctor today who said I have a small fissure ( tear) down below which keeps bleeding everytime I go....she prescribed lactulose which i will take tonight. The black stools probably down to the iron tablets I am taking so am not going to take them for a few days to see if that is the case. Feel much better in myself now that I have some answers! Thank you all again for the support. Xx
Posts.Title: FEC - sorry...question about piles and black stools!!

Posts.Content: Hi All, I apologise for the content of this discussion but I am feeling kind of desperate! I had my third cycle of FEC last week and although I have not been constipated I have ended up with a very sore bottom with piles! I have been using anusol ointment and yesterday I also bought some suppositories to try...but again this morning has been very painful and there was also blood when I went to the loo! Sorry TMI ! Anyone else had this problem? Also, when I was at the chemist yesterday discussing this problem with the pharmacist (who turns out to be Macmillan trained) she asked about the colour of my stools?! When I told her they have been black ever since I started the FEC treatment she seemed quite concerned and told me to get in touch with the oncologist! I had never thought to mention this to him before because I thought it was just all due to the drugs....should I be worried? Anyone else have the same? I know it's not a pleasant topic but I would really appreciate some advice on this! Thanks :) xx
Posts.Title: FEC - sorry...question about piles and black stools!!

Posts.Content: Hi, just wanted to let you know that I had an immediate LD reconstruction following mx in Sept 2011 and I also felt that the recon side was huge even though I did not have any implant. However, over the year the muscle did shrink a fair bit and the size of the breast reduced so I did not have to have any surgery on the other side.....I had also been told that I may need a reduction on the good side to match up. I have recently lost some weight and both breasts have gone down a cup size and still look well matched, I was a 34DD and now 32D. I have to be honest and say that I am still having problems with my back scar and in constant pain/discomfort....back at physio and having electro acupuncture done, there are days when I wish I had just stuck to having an mx as I can't move on with these ongoing problems. I would allow yourself some more time, my surgeon told me to wait at least six months before everything settled down size wise. Wishing you all the best. Xx
Posts.Title: My story was on BBC News. Please, I need your support!

Posts.Content: Glad you've had good news and hope the rest goes well. Your cancer sounds like mine, grade 1 and early stages, I don't need chemo or radiotherapy, just tamoxifen for five years. I also had an LD reconstruction done straight away but nearly four months on am still struggling with the after effects of this major operation. If you don't mind me asking, can you tell me why you are having a gene test and what does this involve? I am asking because there is no family history of breast cancer in my family but I just wonder if I am the " start " of it, I have two daughters and now am so worried for them...don't know if I should be asking for any tests. Xx
Posts.Title: Got my results...

Posts.Content: Hello foxyferret I had a mastectomy and Immediate reconstruction done in Sept 11, following diagnosis of stage 1 er+ cancer. I was lucky not to have to have any chemo or radiotherapy because it was caught early but was put on tamoxifen for five years. However, after taking it for six months I was having some terrible side effects and felt quite ill, I am diabetic as well and after a discussion with my consultant I decided to stop taking the tamoxifen. For me the benefits of taking the drug were very low compared to the effect it was having on the quality of my life. Also, some of the serious side effects combined with the effects of being a diabetic were too scary to put myself through! I think you need to consider everything based on your circumstances and feel happy with the decision you are making, it's your body after all! I had not heard about the Indole 3 carbinol but will look into this for myself as I am open to alternative treatments. Wishing you well x
Posts.Title: I need to make a decision

Posts.Content: Hello all, I have developed cording in my arm five weeks after my surgery even though I have been doing my exercises regularly. Has anyone else had this and can give me some advice on how they managed to sort it out. Thanks in advance xx
Posts.Title: Cording in arm - any advice

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat, just wanted to let you know that I too am having wrist pain and pain/stiffness in both of my thumbs since starting the anastozole ( have been taking it for about six weeks now ). Mentioned to my Gp and she is testing for rheumatiod arthritis!! I am putting it down to the tablets, my oncologist said it was a side effect as well as the muscle pain that I am also getting. Will be having a Dexa scan done in a few weeks to check state of bones! Can you tell me which brand of tablets were better for you, I have the Accord brand and don't know if it is worth trying a different one to see if things get better but I know everyone reacts differently and there could be other side effects with a different brand. Hope things are going well for you x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello All, I am in a bit of a dilemma at the moment with the prospect of having my LD reconstruction removed due to another tumour being found in the breast. I am in Coventry and it has been suggested to me that I get a second opinion and the Royal Marsden was mentioned, so I was wondering if any of you lovely ladies has been treated there, how you found your treatment and if you could recommend a breast surgeon. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Anyone been treated at The Royal Marsden?

Posts.Content: Thank you Kate and Mistymoley for your replies, it has helped in my research for a second opinion. Xx
Posts.Title: Anyone been treated at The Royal Marsden?

Posts.Content: Hey Michellle, I had my op in Sept 2011 and it took the dye well over a year to go, in fact there is still a very feint outline of it left but I don't think it's anything to worry about. If you are concerned just contact your BCN or the nurses on the site. All the best x
Posts.Title: Blue/green dye from Sentinel Node Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Carol Sorry to hear that you are feeling down. I had a mastectomy and immediate LD reconstruction in September and had accepted what had happened to me and been quite positive up until the operation. After it, I really struggled (am still struggling on some days) to accept my new body and have thought that I made the wrong choice of op. In the last few weeks I was beginning to feel better in myself but last week I started taking the tamoxifen and by the end of the week I kept bursting into tears without really knowing why!! I too thought it may be the effect of the tamoxifen or the fact that now the all the hospital appointments, etc., have stopped for a while that I have finally begun to realise what has happened to me and what the long term implications of it are on the rest of my life. Please don't feel alone in dealing with this, talk to your GP or BCN, it may help to have some counselling which is the route I am going to take...there is help out there and you don't have to struggle by yourself. Take care, best wishes. MB
Posts.Title: Dealing with the aftermarth

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say a big thank you to all the lovely ladies who replied to my posts....Wigs and scarves and FEC chemotherapy, I got some really good advice and support which was much appreciated! Seeing oncologist on Thursday to arrange dates, etc. I have decided to have my hair cut short before the chemo starts and to donate it to the Little Princess charity, who provide wigs for children suffering from cancer....need to feel some good is going to come out of this horrible time. Thanks again xx
Posts.Title: Thank you for your replies
